analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received March 16, 2018; revised November 12, 2018 and February 12, 2019; accepted February 12, 2019.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper studies the problem of event-triggered optimal control (ETOC) for continuous-time nonlinear systems and proposes a novel event-triggering condition that enables designing ETOC methods directly based on the solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation. We provide formal performance guarantees by proving a predetermined upper bound. Moreover, we also prove the existence of a lower bound for interexecution time. For implementation purposes, an adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) method is developed to realize the ETOC using a critic neural network (NN) to approximate the value function of the HJB equation. Subsequently, we prove that semiglobal uniform ultimate boundedness can be guaranteed for states and NN weight errors with the ADP-based ETOC. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed ADP-based ETOC method.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A DAPTIVE dynamic programming (ADP) is an effec- tive technique to solve optimal control problems. Such problems often require solving a complicated nonlinear partial differential equation called the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation [1]. However, it is usually difficult to obtain the exact solution of the HJB equation. To overcome this difficulty, a popular methodology is to solve the optimal control problems approximately using ADP [2]- [18]. For instance, Vrabie and Lewis [4] propose an integral reinforcement learning method based on policy iteration for optimal control with partially unknown system dynamics. For affine nonlinear continuous-time systems with input constraints, an approximate solution to the HJB equation can be obtained with a sequence of Lyapunov equations in [2]. This solution requires the knowledge of complete system dynamics. In [9], this requirement is avoided with an online policy iteration algorithm, which can be implemented with an actor-critic neural network (NN) structure. In [11], an off-policy learning method was developed, where system data can be generated by arbitrary control policies. In [13], an ADP method was proposed for nonaffine nonlinear systems with unknown dynamics. To relax the persistence of excitation condition, a model-based reinforcement learning method was suggested in [16], using a concurrent-learning-based system identifier to simulate experience. Note that these works are mainly timetriggered approaches, where the controller needs to stay active at all time instances, which can be expensive in terms of computational and communication overhead.

In many practical applications, it is often unnecessary and/or infeasible to update the controller at every time instance. Event-triggered control [19]- [21] is a promising methodology for reducing computational and communication costs, which has attracted considerable attention in the past few years. Event-triggered control methods only update control action when an event-triggering condition is violated. Recently, ADP methods have been applied to solve eventtriggered optimal control (ETOC) problems in [22]- [30]. Vamvoudakis [22] proposed a novel optimal adaptive eventtriggered control algorithm for continuous-time nonlinear systems. In [23], an actor-critic method was employed to solve the finite-horizon optimal control problem with event-based approximation. In [28], the ETOC problem was investigated for partially unknown continuous-time systems with input constraints. In [31], the ETOC problem for discrete-time nonlinear systems was considered, and an adaptive eventtriggered control method based on heuristic dynamic programming was proposed. In [30], an interesting Q-learning algorithm was developed to solve the model-free ETOC of continuous-time linear systems. For the ETOC problem for continuous-time nonlinear systems, most of the works derive an event-triggered HJB equation, and then apply ADP methods to obtain its solution approximately. Note that the eventtriggered HJB equation itself is already an approximation of the original HJB equation. Moreover, how event-triggered schemes affect the optimal performance index has rarely been studied in existing works.

In traditional optimal control with a time-triggered scheme, the optimal performance index can be attained in theory. However, due to the use of an event-triggered scheme in ETOC, the optimal performance will degrade to some extent. Hence, ETOC essentially provides a tradeoff between the performance and resources usage. Then, a natural question is how much performance degradation an ETOC method causes. In [22] and [30], the real performance index was analyzed for event-triggered control. However, the obtained real performance index contains an integral term and its boundness was not analyzed. In this paper, an ETOC method is developed by proposing a novel event-triggering condition, which guarantees a predetermined upper bound for performance index. Moreover, the stability and the lower bound of interexecution times of ETOC are analyzed theoretically. For realization purpose, ADP is employed to implement the ETOC by using a critic NN to estimate the solution of the HJB equation. It is proven that semiglobal uniform ultimate boundedness (SGUUB) can be guaranteed for states and NN weight errors with the ADP-based ETOC. Furthermore, the bounds for performance and interexecution time are also analyzed for the ADP-based ETOC.

The rest of this paper is arranged as follows. The problem description for ETOC is given in Section II. An ETOC method is proposed and its stability, the upper bound of performance index, and the lower bound of interexecution times are analyzed theoretically in Section III. An ADP-based ETOC method is developed with theoretical analysis in Section IV. Simulation results are presented in Section V, and brief conclusions are given in Section VI.

Notations: R n is the set of n-dimensional Euclidean space and • denotes its norm. N denotes the set of nonnegative integers. The superscript T is used for the transpose of a matrix or vector. ∇ x ∂/∂ x denotes a gradient operator notation. For a symmetric matrix M, M > (≥)0 means that it is a positive definite (semidefinite) matrix. v 2 M v T Mv for some real vector v and symmetric matrix M > (≥)0 with appropriate dimensions. X and U represent two compact sets. C 1 (X ) is a function space on X with first derivatives are continuous. σ (•) and σ (•) denote the maximum and minimum singular values. For a vector x(t), denote x -(t) lim ε→0 x(t -ε).

div.head: II. PROBLEM DESCRIPTION
div.p: Consider the following continuous-time nonlinear systems:
div.formula: where x = [x 1 , • • • , x n ] T ∈ X ⊂ R n is the state, x 0 is the initial state, and u = [u 1 , • • • , u m ] T ∈ U ⊂ R m is the control input. Assume that f (x) + g(x)u(t)
div.p: is Lipschitz continuous on X that contains the origin, f (0) = 0, and that the system is stabilizable on X , i.e., there exists a continuous control function such that the system is asymptotically stable on X . Consider the following infinite-horizon performance index:

where R > 0 and Q(x) is a positive definite function, i.e., Q(x) > 0 for all x = 0 and Q(0) = 0. For the timetriggered optimal control problem, it aims to design a control u(t) = u * (x) such that the system (1) is closed-loop asymptotically stable, and the performance index (2) is minimized. Then, the time-triggered optimal control is given by
div.formula: u * (x) = arg min u J (x 0 , u). (3
div.p: In this paper, the ETOC problem is considered, where the system information only transmits when the event-triggering condition is violated. The triggered instants are a monotone increasing sequence {t j } determined by the event-triggering condition, where t 0 = 0, t j < t j +1 , j ∈ N. Thus, the interexecution time of the event-triggered control is defined as

For the ETOC problem, only at event-triggered instants, the system information is transmitted to the controller and the control signal is held constant in a zero-order-hold scheme during time interval [t j , t j +1 ).

In this paper, the study on the ETOC problem aims to achieve the following three goals. First, a predetermined upper bound can be guaranteed for the real performance index; second, there exists a lower bound for the interexecution time; and third, the stability of the closed-loop system with the ETOC can be guaranteed.

div.head: III. EVENT-TRIGGERED OPTIMAL CONTROL WITH PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE
div.p: In this section, the ETOC method is developed and its theoretical analysis is provided. First, the ETOC is designed directly based on the HJB equation and a novel event-triggering condition is proposed. Based on the developed ETOC, the stability and performance bound are proved for the closed-loop system. Subsequently, it is proven that there exists a lower bound for the interexecution times.

div.head: A. Event-Triggered Optimal Control Design
div.p: First, let us consider the time-triggered optimal control of the system (1) and the performance index (2). For an admissible control u(x), its value function is defined as
div.formula: V u (x) = ∞ t Q(x(t)) + u(x(t)) 2 R dt (5) for all x(t) = x ∈ X , where V u (x) ∈ C 1 (X ), V u (x) 0, and V u (0) = 0. For a value function V u (x) ∈ C 1 (X ), its Hamiltonian is denoted as H (x, u(x), ∇ x V u (x)) = [∇ x V u (x)] T [ f (x) + g(x)u(x)] +Q(x) + u(x) 2 R . (6
div.p: By using (6), differentiating (5) with respect to t yields
For the optimal control u * (x) in (3), denote its optimal value function as V * (x) V u * (x). Then, it follows from (2) that the optimal performance index is given by
div.formula: J * (x 0 ) min u J (x 0 , u) = V * (x 0 ). (8
div.p: From the optimal control theory [1], V * (x) satisfies the following HJB equation:
div.formula: min u H (x, u(x), ∇ x V * (x)) = 0.(9)
div.p: Then, ∇ u H (x, u(x), ∇ x V * (x)) = 0, that is,

div.formula: x(t) = x(t) t = t j x(t j ) t ∈ (t j , t j +1 )(14)
div.p: for all j ∈ N. Note that the ETOC (13) depends on the solution V * (x) of the HJB equation (12). Remark 1: For the time-triggered optimal control u * (x), it requires system state x at all time instants. Differently, in the ETOC (13), only system state at triggered instants is transmitted to the controller and holds constant during the execution interval, which greatly reduces computational and communication resources.
The error between the available state x(t) and true state x(t) is defined as
With the ETOC (13), it follows from ( 1) and ( 15) that the closed-loop system is given by

div.formula: C α (x, x) (1 + α)∇ T x V * (x)[ f (x) + g(x)μ( x)] +Q(x) + μ( x) 2 R (18
div.p: with α > 0 being a pregiven constant that will determine an upper bound for the performance index with the ETOC (13).
Once the triggering condition ( 17) is violated, the current state x(t) is transmitted to update the controller. Thus, it follows from (17) that the next release time instant t j +1 is given by
div.formula: t j +1 = inf{t|C α (x(t), x(t)) 0, t t j }(19)
div.p: where t 0 = 0.

div.head: B. Stability and Performance Guarantee
div.p: For the time-triggered optimal control (10), the performance index (2) can be minimized, i.e., the optimal performance index J * (x 0 ) will be obtained. In the ETOC (13), only states at event-triggered time instants {t j } are available for control update. That is to say, the performance index is bound to degrade at some extent, that is, the optimal performance index cannot be achieved whenever any event-triggering scheme is employed. Thus, it is necessary to analyze that how much the performance index will degrade for an event-triggered control method. For the proposed event-triggering condition ( 17), we will demonstrate in Theorem 1 that an upper bound of the performance index with the ETOC ( 13) can be predetermined by giving the parameter α. Moreover, the stability of the closed-loop system (16) will also be proved in Theorem 1.
Theorem 1: Consider the closed-loop system ( 16) with the triggering condition (17). The triggering instant sequence {t j } is determined by (19). Then:
1) the closed-loop system ( 16) is asymptotically stable;

2) there exists an upper bound for the real performance index J (x 0 , μ), i.e., J (x 0 , μ) (1 + α)J * (x 0 ). Proof: 1) Choose V * (x) as the Lyapunov function. Based on (17) and (19), taking derivative along (16) yields
which means that the closed-loop system ( 16) is asymptotically stable.
2) According to (20), we have
for t ∈ [t j , t j +1 ) and all j . From 1) of Theorem 1, the closedloop system ( 16) is asymptotically stable, which means that lim t →∞ x(t) = 0. Then, based on (2), (8), and ( 21), we have
This completes the proof.

From Theorem 1, it is observed that with the given of the parameter α, the real performance index J (x 0 , μ) is upper bounded by the predetermined (1 + α)J * (x 0 ). In Corollaries 1 and 2, we will analyze the influence of the parameter α in the event-triggering condition (17) to the performance.

Corollary 1: Consider the closed-loop system ( 16) with the triggering condition (17). The sequence of interexecution times {h j } is implicitly determined by (19). If α = 0, then h j = 0 for all j and J (x 0 , μ) = J * (x 0 ).
Proof: Based on the HJB equation ( 12), we have
With the condition α = 0, it follows from ( 18) and ( 22) that
div.formula: C α (x, x) = ∇ T x V * (x)[ f (x) + g(x)μ( x)] + Q(x) + μ( x) 2 R = u * (x) 2 R -2[u * (x)] T Rμ( x) + μ( x) 2 R = u * (x) -μ( x) 2 R 0
div.p: for all t t j and j . Thus, it follows from (19) that t j +1 = t j , i.e., h j = 0 for all j . On the one hand, it follows from the condition α = 0 and 2) of Theorem 1 that J (x 0 , μ) J * (x 0 ). On the other hand, J * (x 0 ) is the minimum performance, which means that J (x 0 , μ) J * (x 0 ). Thus, we have J (x 0 , μ) = J * (x 0 ).

Corollary 2: Let α 1 α 2 > 0. Consider the closed-loop system (16) and the triggering condition (17) with parameters α 1 and α 2 . h α 1 and h α 2 are the interexecution times associate with the parameters α 1 and α 2 . Then, h α 1 h α 2 .
Proof:
, it follows from ( 18) and ( 19) that
div.formula: C α 1 (x, x) -C α 2 (x, x) = (α 1 -α 2 )∇ T x V * (x)[ f (x) + g(x)μ( x)] = α 1 -α 2 1 + α 2 C α 2 (x, x) -Q(x) -μ( x) 2 R - α 1 -α 2 1 + α 2 Q(x) + μ( x) 2 R 0 which means C α 1 (x, x) C α 2 (x, x). Thus, h α 1 h α 2 .
div.p: By using the parameter α = 0, it is observed from Corollary 1 that the ETOC will degrade into a traditional time-triggered optimal control, i.e., h j = 0, and the optimal performance J * (x) can be achieved. From Corollary 2, it is noted that larger α will result in a larger interexecution time, and then more computational and communication resources can be reduced. This is to say, α is a tuning parameter between the ETOC and the time-triggered optimal control, which achieves a tradeoff between the optimal performance index and the reduction of resources. For the choice of α, it depends on practical requirement. If designers emphasize on optimizing the performance index, a small α can be used. Otherwise, a large α can be applied if designers emphasize on reducing computational and communication resources.

div.head: C. Lower Bound of Interexecution Times
div.p: In this section, it is proven that there exists a lower bound for the interexecution time h j . Before starting, the following assumption is required.
div.formula: Assumption 1: Assume that l 1 x 2 Q(x) l 2 x 2 and l 3 x u * (x) l 4 x, where l 1 , l 2 , l 3 , l 4 > 0. Assumption 2: Assume that u * (x) is Lipschitz continuous. For all x 1 , x 2 ∈ X , there exists l u > 0 such that u * (x 1 ) - u * (x 2 ) l u x 1 -x 2 .
div.p: Theorem 2: Consider the closed-loop system (16) with the triggering condition (17). The triggering instant t j is determined by (19) and the interexecution time h j is defined by (4). Let Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then, there exists a lower bound h > 0 for h j , i.e., h j h for all j .

Remark 2: It is worth mentioning that some related works [24], [25], [27], [30], [32] have already been reported to solve the ETOC problems for continuous-time systemsbased ADP. Compared with these existing works, there are two main differences in the proposed ETOC method. First and the most important, the real performance index of event-triggered control methods was rarely analyzed in existing works. For the proposed event-triggering condition (17), it is proven that an upper bound can be guaranteed for the real performance index. Moreover, a tradeoff between the optimal performance index and the reduction of resources can be achieved by tuning the parameter α in (17). Second, in the existing works, the socalled event-triggered HJB equation is usually required. However, it means that V * (x) should satisfy both the HJB equation and the event-triggered HJB equation, which is unreasonable to some extent. For the proposed ETOC method, the eventtriggered HJB equation is not required. It only requires to solve the original HJB equation ( 12) directly, which is much simpler and more reasonable.

div.head: IV. REALIZATION WITH ADAPTIVE DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING
div.p: Note that the ETOC (13) depends on the solution V * (x) of the HJB equation (12). To realize the ETOC, ADP is employed to solve the HJB equation directly online, and then an ADP-based ETOC method is developed. By using a critic NN to estimate the optimal value function V * (x), its weights are tuned to minimize the squared residual error of the HJB equation. Subsequently, the stability of the closedloop system, the bounds for the real performance index, and the interexecution time are analyzed for the developed ADP-based ETOC.

div.head: A. Adaptive Dynamic Programming-Based ETOC
div.p: To solve the HJB equation ( 12), a critic NN is employed to approximate its solution V * (x). Then, V * (x) can be represented as
div.formula: V * (x) = L j =1 θ * j ψ j (x) + (x) (35) where θ * [θ * 1 , • • • , θ * L ] T is the vector of the ideal critic NN weights, L (x) [ψ 1 (x), • • • , ψ L (x)]
div.p: T denotes the vector of critic NN activation functions, and (x) is the NN estimation error that satisfies lim L→∞ (x) = 0. Although θ * provides the best approximation for V * (x), it is usually unknown and difficult to obtain. In realization, the output of the critic NN is
div.formula: V (x) = L j =1 θ j ψ j (x) = T L (x)θ (36
div.p: where θ
T is the estimation of the ideal weight vector θ * . By using (36), it follows from ( 13) that the ADP-based ETOC is given by

div.p: To learn the critic NN weight vector θ , the ADP method is developed. Inspired by works [33]- [35], the following assumption is introduced.
Assumption 3: Let P(x) ∈ C 1 (X ) be a Lyapunov function candidate that satisfies
Moreover, ∇ x P(x) is bounded on the compact set X , i.e., ∇ x P P x M , where P x M > 0.

Due to the estimation error in the critic NN, the replacement of V * (x) and u * (x) in the HJB equation (11) with V (x) and μ(x) will result in a residual error, which means H (x, μ(x), ∇ x V (x)) = 0. Thus, define the residual error between H (x, μ(x), ∇ x V (x)) and H (x, u * (x), ∇ x V * (x)) as follows:

where ∇ T x L (x) [∇ x L (x)] T and ∇ x L (x) denotes the Jacobian of L (x). Based on (41), the square residual error is denoted as follows:
Then, it is desired to tune θ such that the square residual error (42) is minimized and the system stability can be guaranteed. Therefore, the following tuning rule is developed:
div.formula: θ = -βσ (x)ξ(x, θ)γ(x) +κ∇ x L (x)g(x)R -1 g T (x)∇ x P(x) (43)
div.p: where β > 0 is an adaptive gain and
div.formula: γ(x) ∇ x L (x)[ f (x) + g(x)μ(x)] (44) σ (x) 1 1 + γ T (x)γ(x) (45) κ 0 if ∇ T x P(x)[ f (x) + g(x)μ( x)] 0 0.5 else. (46
div.p: The key advantage of ( 46) is that it avoids requiring an initial admissible control policy, and thus, the initial NN weights θ(0) of (43) can be selected randomly. Similar techniques have also been applied and analyzed in related ADP works [33], [34].

Remark 3: It is necessary to give a brief description for the implementation of the ADP-based ETOC. First, the critic NN weight θ is computed with (43) using x, and the eventtriggering condition (39) is verified using x and x. Then, when the event-triggering condition is violated, i.e., C α (x, x) 0, x and θ are transmitted to compute the control with (37) and held constant in a zero-order-hold scheme.

div.head: B. Theoretical Analysis
div.p: In this section, some theoretical analyses are provided for the ADP-based ETOC method (37), including stability, performance bound, and interexecution time bound. The proof the system stability in Theorem 3 is in part inspired by the works [32], [34], [36]. Before starting, Assumption 4 and the definition of SGUUB are given as follows.

Definition 1: [37] Consider the system ( 16), the solution x(t) is SGUUB, if for all x(t 0 ) = x 0 ∈ X , there exist positive constants μ 1 and T (μ 1 , x 0 ) such that x(t) < μ 1 for all t > t 0 + T .
Assumption 4: Assume that: 1) θ * is bounded, i.e., θ * θ M , where
div.formula: θ M > 0; 2) f (x) is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., for all x 1 , x 2 ∈ X , there exists l f > 0 such that f (x 1 )-f (x 2 ) l f x 1 - x 2 . f (x)
div.p: and g(x) are bounded on the compact set X , i.e., f f M and g g M , where f M , g M > 0; 3) L (x) and ∇ x L (x) are bounded on the compact set X , i.e., L M and ∇ x L d M , where M , d M > 0; 4) ∇ x (x) is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., for all x 1 , x 2 ∈ X , there exists
div.formula: l d > 0 such that ∇ x (x 1 ) -∇ x (x 2 ) l d x 1 -x 2 .
div.p: (x) and ∇ x (x) are bounded on the compact set X , i.e., M and ∇ x x M , where M , x M > 0; 5) γ(x) is bounded on the compact set X , i.e., γ m γ(x) γ M , where γ m , γ M > 0. Define the error of critic NN weights as θ(t) θ(t) -θ * . Then, it follows from (43) that

div.p: With Assumptions 1 and 4, the first term in (54) is

div.p: Based on the definition of κ in ( 46), it has two cases.

Theorem 4: Consider the system (1) with control (37). Let Assumptions 1-4 hold. Then:

1) there exists an upper bound for the real performance index Ĵ (x 0 , μ); 2) there exists a lower bound h > 0 for h j , i.e., h j h for all j . Proof: For the proof of Theorem 4, it is expected that the ADP has achieved the desired convergence, i.e., θ * is obtained.

div.p: the rest of proof is the same as that for Theorem 2, which is omitted to avoid repetition.

In Theorem 3, the stability for the ADP-based eventtriggered control is provided. In Theorem 4, it is proven that there exists an upper bound for the real performance index and a lower bound for the interexecution times. From the proof, when the NN estimation error (x) → 0, the upper bound for the real performance index and the lower bound for the interexecution times will approach to the ideal values.

Remark 4: In [22] and [30], some important theoretical results were given to analyze the real performance index for event-triggered control. Comparing this paper with [22] and [30], there are three main differences. First, in [22] and [30], the real performance index for the eventtriggered control contains an integral term
div.formula: ∞ 0 (u * c -u * d ) T R(u * c -u * d )dt.
div.p: However, the boundness of this integral term was not analyzed. In this paper, an upper bound of the real performance index can be determined for a given parameter α.

Moreover, the upper bound is also analyzed under the consideration of NN estimation error by using ADP implementation. Second, in this paper, the ADP method is developed to solve the original HJB equation ( 12) directly. In [22], the ADP was employed to solve the event-triggered HJB equation, which can be viewed as approximation for the original HJB equation. Third, because the event-triggering condition in this paper is different from those in [22] and [30], their theoretical analysis is greatly different.

div.head: V. SIMULATION STUDIES
div.p: In this section, the effectiveness of the ETOC is verified on three examples: a power system, satellite attitude control system, and a nonlinear torsional pendulum system. Moreover, to show the influence of the parameter α in the event-triggering condition, comparative simulation studies are conducted with different α.

div.head: A. Case 1: Power System
div.p: The system dynamics of the linear power system is given as follows:
where the system matrices are given by

the system state vector is x = [ f, P g , X g ] T and u is the control input. f, P g , and X g denote the incremental frequency deviation, the incremental change in the generator output, and the incremental change in governor valve position, respectively. T g = 0.2, T t = 5, T p = 2, K p = 0.5, and R 0 = 0.5 denote the governor time constant, the turbine time constant, the plant model time constant, the plant gain, and the speed regulation due to governor action, respectively. For the performance index (2), let R = 1 and Q(x) = x T Sx with an identity matrix S. Then, the HJB equation ( 12) can be solved exactly and its solution is given by V * (x) = x T Px, where By using the optimal value function V * (x), the ETOC ( 13) is applied to the power system. For the event-triggering condition (18), select the parameter α = 0.05. The simulation results are demonstrated in Figs. 1234. Figs. 123show the trajectories of the state x and x, the ETOC μ, and the interexecution times h j , respectively. It is found in Fig. 3 that the minimum h j is 0.5001s, which shows that the communication of state information and the computation of control are greatly reduced. Moreover, the optimal performance index J * (x 0 ), the real performance index J (x 0 , μ), and the bound (1 + α)J * (x 0 ) are shown in Fig. 4, where the upper bound of the real performance is guaranteed, i.e., J (x 0 , μ) (1+α)J * (x 0 ).

div.head: B. Case 2: Satellite Attitude Control System
div.p: For the satellite model considered in [39] and [40], its equations of motion are

where ϑ 1 is the angle of the main satellite with respect to the star, ϑ 2 is the angle between the star sensor and the instrument package, k = 0.09 is a torque constant, d = 0.0219 is a viscous damping constant, J 1 = 1 and J 2 = 1 are inertias, Fig. 4. For Case 1, the trajectories of J * (x 0 ), J (x 0 , μ) and the bound (1 + α)J * (x 0 ). and T c is the control torque. Denoting x = [ϑ 2 , θ2 , ϑ 1 , θ1 ] T and u = T c , the system (64) can be rewritten as (63), where

For the performance index (2), let R = 1 and Q(x) = x T Sx with an identity matrix S. Let the parameter α = 0.05 for event-triggering condition. The simulation results are shown IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS AND LEARNING SYSTEMS Fig. 7. For Case 2, the trajectory of the ETOC μ. Fig. 8. For Case 2, the interexecution time h j . Fig. 9. For Case 2, the trajectories of J * (x 0 ), J (x 0 , μ) and the bound (1 + α)J * (x 0 ). in Figs. 56789. Figs. 567shows the trajectories of states and control. The intertimes h j are shown in Fig. 8, where the achieved minimum h j is 0.1201 s. In Fig. 9, it is observed that the achieved real performance is J (x 0 , μ) = 15.6072, which is below the upper bound (1 + α)J * (x 0 ).

div.head: C. Case 3: Torsional Pendulum System
div.p: The nonlinear torsional pendulum system [41] is given by ⎧ where u is the control input, M = 1 kg is the mass, and l = 3 m is the length of the pendulum bar. Denote the system state as x = [ϑ, ω] T , where ϑ and ω are the current angle and angular velocity with initial values given by ϑ(0) = 0.2 and ω(0) = -0.2, respectively. g = 9.8m/s 2 is the gravity, J = (4Ml 2 /3) is the rotary inertia, and f d is the frictional factor. For the performance index (2), R = 1 and Q(x) = x T Sx with S being an identity matrix.
div.formula: ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ dϑ dt = ω J dω dt = u -Mgl sin(ϑ) -f d ω(65)
div.p: To approximate the value function of the HJB equation, select the NN activation functions as L (x) = [x 2 1 , x 1 x 2 , x 2 2 , x 3 1 , x 2 1 x 2 , x 1 x 2 2 , x 3 2 , x 4 1 , x 3 1 x 2 , x 2 1 x 2 2 , x 1 x 3 2 , x 4 2 ] T . For the eventtriggering condition (18), select the parameter α = 0.8. Then, the ADP-based ETOC is applied to the torsional pendulum system. Figs. 4-13 demonstrate the trajectories of the state x and x, the NN weight θ , the ETOC μ, the event-triggering condition C α (x, x), and the interexecution times h j , respectively. In Fig. 13, it is found that the minimum h j is 0.0220 s.

div.head: D. Case 4: Event-Triggering Condition With Larger α
div.p: To study the influence of the parameter α, we conduct simulation on the satellite attitude control system (64) with a larger parameter α = 0.5, and other parameters remain the same as that for Case 2. The simulation results are demonstrated in Figs. 14-18. Compared with Fig. 8 with Fig. 17, it is found that the achieved minimum h j is 0.3203s for Case 4, which is less than that for Case 2. Compared with Fig. 9 with Fig. 18, it is observed that the achieved real performance is J (x 0 , μ) = 15.3893 for Case 4, which is larger than that for Case 2. This is to say, the parameter α achieves a tradeoff between the performance index and the reduction of resources, which verifies the analysis in Remark 2.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: For the optimal control problem of nonlinear continuoustime systems, a novel event-triggering condition is proposed for ETOC design. It is proven that the developed ETOC method can guarantee an upper bound for the real performance index. Moreover, the stability of the closed-loop system and the existence of a lower bound for interexecution times have been analyzed. To solve the HJB equation, the critic NN was used to approximate the optimal value function and the ADP-based ETOC method has been developed. The stability, the bounds for the performance index, and the interexecution time have been proved. In the simulation studies, the effectiveness of the developed ETOC method was verified on four cases.

There are some related interesting topics that will be studied in the future. First, study the model-free ETOC methods with performance guarantee. Second, study event-triggering schemes to update the critic NN weights. Third, study practical applications for the developed ADP-based ETOC method.
